case_vignette: A 35-year-old African American fema   le presents for evaluation of a painless tongue growth present for the past three months. She denies biting the site or any    inciting    trauma. She noted it when brushing he r teeth and it has    slowly grown in size. Physical examinat ion reveals a pink nodule on the right mid-tongue. An excisional biopsy is performed and    reveals pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia and  collections of large polygonal cells with abundant cytoplasm and small cytoplasmic inclusions in the derm   is.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm here because I have a painless growth on my tongue that I noticed about three months ago.
Has the size or appearance of the growth changed since you first noticed it?
Yes, it has slowly grown in size since I first noticed it.
Does the growth have a particular color or texture? Is it hard or soft?
The growth is pink and it's a nodule located on the right middle part of my tongue.
Do you have any other symptoms such as difficulty swallowing, speaking, or changes in taste?
No, I don't have any other symptoms like difficulty swallowing, speaking, or changes in taste.
Do you have any history of smoking, alcohol use, or similar habits?
I haven't mentioned any such habits in my history.
Have you had any similar issues in the past, or do you have a family history of any oral or systemic diseases?
No, I haven't had any similar issues in the past, and I haven't mentioned any family history of oral or systemic diseases.
Final Diagnosis: Oral fibroma
